question: Question_06_(d)
statement:
Consider the curve $x^2+y^3-2xy=0$. Assume that the point \emph{(x,y) =
(1,1)} lies on the curve, and that nearby points on the curve satisfy
\emph{y=f(x)} for some function of \emph{f(x)}.

Write down the quadratic approximation of \emph{f(x)} at \emph{x=1}.
Sketch its graph in the \emph{x,y} grid below.
sols:
Plugging in the values from
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH104/December_2012/Question_6_(a)}{part
(a)} and
\href{Science:Math_Exam_Resources/Courses/MATH104/December_2012/Question_6_(b)}{part
(b)} into the second degree Taylor polynomial (recalling the a value is
1) gives

\begin{align*}
T_{2}(x) &= f(1) + f'(1)(x-1) + f''(1)(x-1)^{2}/2 \\
&= 1 + (0)(x-1) + (-2)(x-1)^{2}/2 \\
&= 1 - (x-1)^{2} \\
&= -x^2+2x\\
&= x(2-x)
\end{align*}

The graph is given below.

hints:
Quadratic approximations are given by second degree Taylor polynomials
which are given by

$\displaystyle T_{2}(x) = f(1) + f'(1)(x-1) + f''(1)(x-1)^{2}/2$

Compute this, then graph.
